title-group.article-title: Micromechanical-based hybrid mesoscopic 3D approach for non-linear progressive failure analysis of composite structures

article-meta.aff: ONERA/DMSC, 29 avenue de la Division Leclerc, Châtillon cedex, France

author-notes.corresp: N Carrere, ONERA/DMSC, 29 avenue de la Division Leclerc, BP 72, F-92322 Châtillon cedex, France Email: nicolas.carrere@ensta-bretagne.fr

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue: Evaluation of Theories for Predicting Failure in Polymer Composite Laminates Under 3-D States of Stress: Part A of the Second World-Wide Failure Exercise (WWFE-II)

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: A new micromechanical-based hybrid mesoscopic 3D approach has presented for the prediction of failure under triaxial loadings. The failure criterion is based on physical principles and introduces micromechanical aspects (such as the effect of the local debonding) at the mesoscopic scale. It is capable of distinguishing between various modes of failure (e.g. fibre tension, fibre compression, in-plane and through-thickness interfibre (matrix or fibre/matrix failure modes). The model was successfully implemented to provide predictions of failure envelopes and non-linear stress–strain curves of isotropic, unidirectional and mutli-directional laminates made of glass/epoxy and carbon/epoxy materials and subjected to 3D loadings, including through-thickness stresses.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Prediction of mechanical behaviour until final failure of composite materials is an absolute necessity in order to obtain a sufficient degree of confidence in the design of engineering composite structures. It has been demonstrated during the first “World Wide Failure Exercise” (WWFE), proposed in Hinton et al.1 and devoted to the comparison of different multiscale failure approaches under plane stress loadings, that the most mature approaches permit a correct description of the failure of classical laminates. However, the conclusions of the exercise were (1) the modellings of the behaviour and of the rupture of highly disoriented composites are in very poor agreement with the experimental results and (2) all the approaches overestimate drastically the strength of every kind of layup in compression (because these material approaches neglect failure through buckling of the tested tubes). We have recently proposed a mesoscopic multiscale progressive failure approach which permits to overcome these problems. This approach2 is based on viscoelastic and damage models allowing a correct description of the non-linear behaviour of [±θ]s laminates and of the effect of a failed ply on the mechanical properties of the laminate. Moreover, this approach has been implemented in a finite element (FE) code to perform calculations on composite structures. The predictions of the final failure of thin tubes subjected to compressive loadings, using FE calculations performed in order to take into account the effect of buckling, are in this case in good agreement with the experimental results.3

However, other key problems remain very sensitive. The first one concerns the prediction of the strength of high stress gradient parts of the structures. In this case, the simplest methods consist in calculating a failure criterion with a progressively “updated” stress in order to describe accurately the experimental data. We have recently compared the predictions of these kinds of approaches using tensile tests on different multiperforated plates. An alternative approach, called a critical damage area method, has also been proposed. This approach considers that the final failure of a structure occurs when a given critical volume is broken.4 Moreover, a physically based approach, however more costly in computational time, has also been developed. This approach describes quantitatively the progressive aspect of fibre failures (FFs) in the structure and their effects (huge degradation) without becoming mesh dependent by the use of adapted numerical tools. The predictions of this model have been compared with the experimental data and the results are in quite good agreement with the experimental data. The second identified key problem concerns the strength analysis of structures subjected to triaxial loadings which could be (1) directly applied (for instance unfolding tests on corner L-angle) or (2) induced by free-edge effects. These 3D problems are those addressed in the present exercise. In fact, the majority of the test cases investigated in the present framework concerns the effect of out-of-plane loadings on the in-plane failure (8 test cases out of 11 which concern composite applications) and only “volume” failure is investigated (it means that delamination is not taken into account, out-of-plane rupture being due to inner failure of the ply).

The aim of the present paper is to propose a multiscale micromechanical-based hybrid mesoscopic (MHM) progressive failure approach which improves the determination of the final failure of the laminate under complex triaxial loadings. The “micromechanical-based hybrid mesoscopic” model is used for an approach written at the scale of a ply but with some micromechanical aspects introduced at the mesoscopic scale. The progressive aspect of the laminate failure is taken into account, it means that after a first ply failure, the mechanical properties of the failed ply are degraded progressively, which reduces the effective rigidity of the laminate and leads to overloading of the other plies.

The paper first describes techniques for various modelling scales and the choice of the current hybrid (MHM) approach and its development and identification procedure used for the model's parameters. A discussion is made on the limitations of the model and how improvements could be made to obtain a more mature analysis.

sec.title: Our point of view on the different possible modelling scales
On the limitation of mesoscopic approaches
sec.p: The majority of the theories proposed during the first WWFE were mesoscopic in nature. These mesoscopic approaches permit to be predictive for different stacking sequences from the strength of the individual unidirectional ply. These kinds of approaches allow introducing all the most important observed mechanisms: (1) the failure could be fibre- or matrix-dominated, (2) after the first ply failure the damage evolves as a function of the applied loading and (3) the behaviour could be non-linear at high strains where the behaviour is matrix-dominated. Moreover, the identification of the parameters necessitates only tests at the UD ply scale. At a practical point of view, no particular difficulty is associated to the implementation of mesoscopic approaches in an FE code and to its use in an industrial design office.

However, some mechanisms could not be taken into account in these mesoscopic theories. For instance, it has been shown that the reinforcement in high shear and weak compression in the interfibre failure (IFF) mode could be explained at a micromechanical point of view: the transverse compressive loading increases the load transfer capability of the fibre/matrix interface and delays the percolation of microdamages which are due to shear loading. Taking into account this reinforcement permits to increase drastically the predicting capabilities of the modelling.5 This is the reason why some authors have made the choice of a micro/meso approach.

sec.title: On the limitation of continuous micro to meso approaches
sec.p: “Continuous micro to meso approach” is used to characterize the behaviour (elastic and non-linear) and the damage of a UD ply using only the data available on fibre and matrix. This scale of modelling poses a huge challenge to the designers as its accuracy is usually difficult to achieve.

In order to study the possibility to use such a method in the framework of this exercise, we have compared the elastic properties obtained by different micromechanical approaches with those provided by the organisers of the exercise at the ply scale.6 Two different approaches have been used:
an analytical approach (the Mori-Tanaka estimation7). The homogenized stiffness tensor C≈hom is given by
(1)T≈ f=[I≈+S≈Esh:C-1≈m:(C≈ f-C≈ m)]-1 With (2)T≈ f=[I≈+S≈Esh:C-1≈m:(C≈ f-C≈ m)]-1 where, C≈m and C≈f are respectively the stiffness tensors of matrix and fibre, vm and vf are, respectively, the matrix and fibre volume fractions. I≈ is the fourth order identity tensor. S≈Esh is the Eshelby tensor.
FE analysis (with various representative volume elements (RVEs): periodic square or periodic hexagonal or with random distribution arrangements of the fibres into the matrix)

The longitudinal modulus of the ply is quite well predicted by the different methods. The transverse and in-plane shear moduli predicted by the different models using the local behaviour provided in this exercise are presented in Figure 1(a) and (b). A high discrepancy could be observed between the predicted values and the experimental ones. Two sources of errors could explain these differences: (1) the limitation of the multiscale approaches and (2) the identification of the local properties. Four different multiscale approaches having been compared, our point of view is that the microscopic properties are not totally consistent with the mesoscopic ones. This discrepancy may be possibly attributed to the matrix (difference between ex-situ (bulk material) and in-situ (matrix in the UD ply) properties) or transverse fibres properties (transverse properties are difficult to measure). Figure 1.
Comparison between the different homogenization methods for the E11 modulus (a) and the E22 modulus (b). The results are normalized with respect to the experimental results.

These results show that even for the elastic properties, a micro to meso approach leads to poor results. The degree of difficulty is even higher for the non-linear behaviour. In order to obtain a good evaluation of the global behaviour, it is necessary to use a very fine description of the local stress gradients. Moreover, the in-situ behaviour is very difficult to identify and very sensitive to the manufacturing process (physico-chemical state of the polymer matrix inside the composite).

Finally, the prediction of the mesoscopic failure using the properties of the local constituents necessitates taking into account (1) the local initiation of the failure due to stress concentration near the fibre (microdamage near the fibre/matrix interface) and (2) the increase in the number of cracks inside the ply. Moreover, taking into account couplings between non-linear behaviour, local damage and failure is necessary in order to achieve satisfactory results.

This paragraph shows that if continuous micro to meso approaches seem very attractive, they necessitate a degree of refinement (of the modelling and of the identification) too high to be applicable in the present framework.

As a conclusion of this section, we have chosen an MHM approach. The main idea is to introduce micromechanical aspects (such as the effect of the local debonding on the non-linear behaviour or on the failure) in a model which is formulated and identified (mainly) at the ply scale.

sec.title: Presentation of the approach proposed by ONERA
sec.p: This section is devoted to the presentation of the MHM theory proposed by Office National d'Études et de Recherches Aérospatiales (ONERA).

sec.title: Micromechanical background
sec.p: A lot of studies have been performed at ONERA during the last 10 years in order to propose micro/meso multiscale approaches. It has been shown that this goal could be achieved in SiC/Ti composites8 in which (1) the arrangement of the fibres into the matrix is quasi-periodic and (2) it is possible to identify by micromechanical tests the in situ behaviour of the matrix, the fibre (ϕ=150 µm) and the interface. For polymer matrix composites, it is possible to predict by multiscale approaches the non-linear behaviour of the UD ply.9 In this case, the physico-chemical state of the matrix (which has a great influence on the non-linear behaviour of the matrix) inside the composite must be taken into account. These difficulties and the limitations shown earlier have led us to use another kind of approach.

However, micromechanical modelling could help building and identifying some parameters of the MHM model. The aim of this section is to present the micromechanical tools used in the following. In order to propose a correct description, all the non-linear, damage and rupture mechanisms must be taken into account. The micro to meso change of scale could be performed using a simple elastic localization rule (extension to non-linear behaviour will be presented later). The local stress and strain fields are connected to the mesoscopic ones by relations using localization (A≈r and B≈r where r denotes the sub-volume r) (3)σ ~ r=B ≈ r:Σ~ (4)ɛ~r=A≈r:E~
The relations between the micro quantities and the mesoscopic ones are given by (5)Σ~=áσ~(x)ñV=∑rvrσ~r (6)E~=áɛ~(x)ñV=∑rvrɛ~r where vr is the volume fraction of sub-volume r.

The non-linearities are due to the viscoelastic behaviour of the matrix. Equation (7) presents the thermo-viscoelastic behaviour which is used to simulate the behaviour of the polymer matrix (7)σ~=C ≈ 0:(ɛ~T-ɛ~th-ɛ~ve) with ɛ~th=α~(T-T0) where σ~, C≈0, ɛ~T, ɛ~th and ɛ~ve are, respectively, the stress, the initial elastic stiffness, the total strain, the thermal strain and the viscoelastic strain tensors. T and T0 are the test temperature and the stress-free temperature.

The thermal strain ɛ~th is defined classically in equation (7), α~ being the thermal expansion tensor. The viscoelastic strain εve is calculated using the non-linear viscoelastic spectral model.10 The main idea of this approach consists in expanding the viscosity into a series of elementary viscous mechanisms (8)ɛ·~ve=g(σ~)∑iξ· ~ i with ξ· ~ i=1τi(μig(σ~)S ≈ r:σ~-ξ ~ i) where S≈r is the viscoelastic compliance. Each elementary viscous mechanism (ξ~i) is defined by its relaxation time (τi) and its weight (mi). These two quantities define the temporal spectrum which is supposed to have a Gaussian form (equation 9). (9)τi=ei mi=1noπexp(-(i-n0nc)2)

In order to describe the non-linear aspect of viscosity,10 a non-linear function, depending only on stress, was introduced into the model (10)T≈ f=[I≈+S≈Esh:C-1≈m:(C≈ f-C≈ m)]-1 where p, υ0 and c are material parameters and < >+ are the Macaulay brackets.

The fourth order tensor M≈d is defined as follows (11)M≈d=aH≈D+bH≈H where a and b are material parameters. These parameters permit to describe the effect of the hydrostatic pressure on the behaviour of the matrix. The fourth order tensors H≈D (deviatoric tensor) and H≈H (hydrostatic tensor) are defined11 such as (12)H≈D=13(1~⊗1~) H≈H=I≈-13(1~⊗1~)

The scenario of damage in polymer matrix composite laminates is now well known. The first damage occurs at the fibre scale (fibre/matrix interface rupture or matrix microcracks). The coalescence of these microdamages through the ply thickness induces transverse cracks. In order to describe these phenomena, it is necessary to describe both debonding and/or failure into the matrix (since debonding could be interpreted as a local failure of the matrix). In the following, we will focus our attention on the failure of the matrix. It is well known that failure in polymer materials could involve two mechanisms: “damage” (crazing in thermoplastic polymers and cavitation in thermosetting polymers) and yielding.12,13

Consequently, we propose a multicriterion where both yielding and crack initiation are considered (as suggested in Ref. [14]):
Yielding is described by a modified Tresca criterion
(13)12(σ1-σ3)=σs 0-μ(σ1+σ2+σ3) where (σ1,σ2,σ3) are the principal stress components defined as σ1>σ2>σ3. σs0 and μ are material parameters.
Damage is described by the following criterion
(14)(áσ1ñ+ m+áσ2ñ+ m+áσ3ñ+ m)1/m=σceq where m and σceq are material parameters.

The shape of this criterion is shown in Figure 2. The present analysis does not distinguish between yield and ultimate failure of the matrix material. It is worth mentioning that under hydrostatic compressive loading, the failure criterion leads to infinite strength. In fact, in a real test, failure could be initiated by a local defect. To describe this phenomenon, a third failure criterion could be proposed for pure hydrostatic failure. However, no experimental result is available to identify this criterion; therefore, this phenomenon is not taken into account in the present exercise. Figure 2.
Shape of the failure criterion proposed for polymer materials.

sec.title: Mesoscopic background
sec.p: The principle of the presented multiscale progressive failure approach2,3 can be divided into four sub-problems: (1) the choice of the mesoscopic behaviour, (2) the definition of a mesoscopic failure criterion, (3) degradation of the properties of the failed plies in the laminate and (4), finally, definition of the final laminate failure.

The mesoscopic behaviour, expressed in the material axes, is described by a thermo-non-linear-viscoelastic behaviour written in a manner similar to that of the matrix (see equations (7–10)), except that the involved tensors respect the transverse isotropic symmetry of the ply.

The proposed failure criterion is based on the Hashin’s assumptions.15 Two failure modes are considered: an FF mode and an IFF. For each failure mode, a distinction is made between the failures in tension and in compression, due to their different failure mechanisms.

The IFF, tension failure (f2 +) and compression failure (f2 -), are modelled by the following failure criteria (15){f2 +=(σ22Y~t)2+(τ12S~c(1-pσ22))2=1 ifσ22≥0f2 -=(σ22Y~c)2+(τ12S~c(1-pσ22))2=1 ifσ22<0 with {Y~t=Yt(1-df)Y~c=Yc(1-df)S~c=Sc(1-df)
where Yt, Yc, Sc are, respectively, the transverse tensile and compressive strengths and the in-plane shear strength. The parameter p is described in Refs [16,17].

The FF, tension failure (f1 +) and compression failure (f1 -), are modelled by the following failure criteria (16)f1 +=(σ11X~t(d2))2=1 with X~t=Xte-h1rd2 +Xt yarn(1-e-h1rd2) ifσ11≥0f1 -=(σ11Xc)2=1 ifσ11<0 where X~t and Xc are, respectively, the efficient longitudinal tensile and compressive strengths of the UD ply. The above equation does not take into account the effect of shear stress on the compressive failure criterion. In a further development, the authors have considered that effect in Refs [16,17].

This model is a first attempt to propose an MHM model, since some micro/meso couplings are introduced. For instance, the coefficient p is used to describe the effect of local debondings on the mesoscopic shear strength (see equation (15)). The degradation variable df (see equation (15)) is used to represent the degradation of the interfibre strengths due to premature failure of single fibres (statistical effect on fibre strength). The last micro/meso coupling concerns the effect of the load capability of the matrix (characterized by the coefficient h1r in equation (16)). In equation (16), Xt and Xt yarn are, respectively, the longitudinal tensile strength of a sound UD ply (undamaged matrix d2 = 0) and of a dry fibre bundle (fully damaged matrix).

Then, the progressive degradation model is based on damage models.18 After the first failure of a ply in the laminate (failure criterion value is higher than 1), the effective elastic compliance S~ of the failed ply is increased (17)T≈ f=[I≈+S≈Esh:C-1≈m:(C≈ f-C≈ m)]-1 where S≈0 is the elastic (initial) compliance, d1H≈1 and d2H≈2 are tensors that represent, respectively, the effect of FF and IFF on the compliance of the broken ply.

This model permits to describe correctly the non-linear behaviour, the progressive failure and the final failure of various laminates.2 This was a first attempt to propose a micromechanical based hybrid theory. In the following, this model will be generalized to 3D loadings (especially concerning the distinction between the different modes or planes of failure).

sec.title: MHM model to describe the mesoscopic behaviour
sec.p: In order to predict correctly a ply failure, it is necessary to have a good estimate of the mesoscopic stresses, the choice of the behaviour at the ply scale is thus essential. The mesoscopic behaviour, expressed in the material axes, is described by the thermo-damage-viscoelastic behaviour presented in equations (7–10) and recalled in the following. All the parameters involved in this model could be identified using suitable mechanical tests on the ply in conjunction with the fibre/matrix properties and by employing a reliable micromechanical approach.9,16,17 (18)σ~=C≈ ~:(ɛ~T-ɛ~th-ɛ~ve) with ɛ~th=α~UD(T-T0) where C≈ ~ is the elastic stiffness tensor of the ply and α~UD is the thermal expansion tensor of the ply. σ~ is the stress in the ply, ɛ~T, ɛ~th and ɛ~ve are, respectively, the total strain, the thermal strain and the viscoelastic strain of the ply.

The viscoelastic strain of the ply is written as follows (19)T≈ f=[I≈+S≈Esh:C-1≈m:(C≈ f-C≈ m)]-1 where S ≈r ~UD is the viscoelastic compliance tensor of the UD ply. The relaxation time and associated weight are those identified on the matrix. The non-linear function g is given by (20)T≈ f=[I≈+S≈Esh:C-1≈m:(C≈ f-C≈ m)]-1 where < >+ are the Macaulay brackets.

The fourth order tensor M≈d UD is defined as follows (21)M≈d UD=aUDB≈m t:H≈D:B≈m+bUDB≈m t:H≈H:B≈m where pUD, σ0UD, aUD, bUD and cUD are ply parameters. These parameters could be assumed equal to those of the matrix, except σ0UD, which necessitates an updating. B≈m is the stress localization tensor of the matrix (see equation (3)).

Micromechanical investigations have evidenced that microdamage could occur before the first mesoscopic crack. These microdamages (fibre/matrix debondings, microcracks into the matrix) are represented by two damage variables (μ2 and μ3), which describe, respectively, microcracks in the (2,3) plane: one perpendicular to axis 2 (μ2) and one to axis 3 (μ3). This local damage could have a strong influence on the viscoelastic compliance tensor expressed as follows (22)S≈ ~r UD=S≈r UD+∑iμi effH≈i ve where H≈i ve are the effect tensors of the effective damage variables μi eff (which take into account de-activation of damage under compressive loadings). S≈r UD is the initial viscoelastic compliance tensor which can be estimated using the matrix properties by (23)S≈r UD=vmB≈m t:S≈r m:B≈m where B≈m is the stress localization tensor, S≈r m is the matrix viscoelastic compliance tensor and vm the matrix volume fraction.

The microdamages are described by a scalar damage model. The evolution of the damage variables are given by (24){ifyi≥yi 0 μi=di c(1-exp-(yi-yi 0yi c)pi)μ·i≥0 where di c, yi 0 and yi c are material parameters (for i = 2, 3). yi are thermodynamic forces given by (25)T≈ f=[I≈+S≈Esh:C-1≈m:(C≈ f-C≈ m)]-1 y3 is given by a simple permutation of the indices in the previous equationwhere ayi, bi, bi ' and py are material parameters. Cm is the elastic stiffness tensor of the matrix. ɛme+ is the positive part of the elastic strain tensor in the matrix ɛ~m. ɛ~m is calculated using the localization equation (26)σ~m=B≈m:Σ~ ɛ~m=S≈m:σ~mɛ~m=S≈m:B≈m:Σ~=K≈m:Σ~ where S≈m is the elastic compliance tensor of the matrix.

A progressive damage de-activation is used as follows (27)μi eff=ηiɛμiwithηi ɛ={ηi ɛ=1ifɛ¯i≥Δɛfηi ɛ=12(1-cos(π2.ɛ¯i+ΔɛfΔσi f))if-Δɛf<ɛ¯i<Δɛfηi ɛ=0if-Δɛf≤ɛ¯i with ɛ¯i=ɛi-Δɛf where εf and Δɛf are material parameters. It is worth mentioning that the effective damage variable μi eff could increase from 0 to ∞.

sec.title: MHM model to describe the mesoscopic failure
sec.p:
Two failure modes are considered: an FF mode and an IFF mode. For each mode, a distinction is made between tension and compression failures (see Figure 3). The tensile failures (FF and IFF) are very similar to those resulting from the model previously developed (see paragraph 3.1.2) but are written in a more general framework. Moreover, the effects of microdamages are now taken into account through the damage variables μ2, μ3 (fibre/matrix debonding, microdamages into the matrix, see 3.2) and μf (effects of premature fibre rupture due to the statistical distribution of fibre strengths). The tensile failure criterion in fibre mode f1 + is given by (28)f1 +=Y1+ eqY1+ 0=1withY1+ eq=σ ~:F≈1 +:σ ~andY1+ 0=1 where F≈1 + is defined as follows (29)F≈1 +=[η1 σX~t 200000000000000000000000000000000000]withη1σ={1ifσ1≥00ifσ1<0 X~t=Xt UDe-h1t(μ2 eff+μ3 eff)+Xt dry(1-e-h1t(μ2 eff+μ3 eff)) where XtUD is the longitudinal tensile strength of a sound UD ply and Xtyarn the strength of a dry fibre bundle. Equation (29) may be interpreted as follows: the effective longitudinal tensile strength of a UD ply (Xt ~) decreases progressively from the initial strength XtUD of a sound UD ply (perfect fibre/matrix load transfer) to the dry fibre bundle strength (Xtyarn), which is equivalent to the strength of a UD ply with a fully degraded matrix. h1t is a material parameter which represents the effect of microdamages on the longitudinal tensile strength of the ply. Figure 3.
The different modes of failure considered in the micromechanical-based hybrid mesoscopic (MHM) criterion. A distinction is made between tension and compression failures. Three modes of rupture are considered: transverse in-plane interfibre mode (a), transverse through-thickness interfibre mode (b) and fibre mode (c).
The in-plane interfibre mode f2 + and out-of-plane mode f3 + are given by (30)T≈ f=[I≈+S≈Esh:C-1≈m:(C≈ f-C≈ m)]-1 where F≈i + is defined as follows (31)T≈ f=[I≈+S≈Esh:C-1≈m:(C≈ f-C≈ m)]-1

where Y~t, Z~t, S~23, S~13 and S~12 are, respectively, the effective transverse tensile strength, the effective through-thickness tensile strength, the effective through-thickness shear strengths and the effective in-plane shear strength. These effective strengths are functions of the microdamages (μ2 eff and μ3 eff) through the parameters h2t, h3t, h23t, h13t and h12t. Finally, Yt 0, Zt 0, S23 0, S13 0 and S12 0 are material parameters which represent the “virtual” strengths without any microdamage.

μf in equation (30) represents the effect of premature single fibre rupture on the IFF tensile strengths. Due to a statistical effect on the strength of the fibres (Weibull distribution), some single FFs occurred under the σ11 uniaxial tension stress long before many FFs lead to the ultimate failure of the UD ply.19 In the vicinity of the fibre breaks, these premature failures lead to interfacial debondings and to the formation of micro cracks in the matrix. It could be supposed that these premature single FFs facilitate the coalescence of micro cracks, thus leading to a decrease in the IFF strengths. The evolution of μf is given by a classical Weibull distribution20 (with threshold) (32)μf=1-exp-(áσ11 f-σ1 0fñ+σ1 cf)m where < >+ are the Macauley brackets. (σ1 0f,m,σ1 cf) are material parameters. σ11 f is the 11 stress component in the fibre, calculated with the localization equation (3).
The compressive FF and IFF are given using an energy criterion. Rupture occurs when the energy in the plane of rupture is greater than a critical value.

Ply rupture in fibre compressive mode is due to the creation of a shear band (see Figure 3). This shear band is very sensitive to local defects (for instance fibre/matrix debondings or initial defects due to the process may facilitate the initiation of this shear band). The compressive failure criterion in fibre mode f1 - is thus given by the maximum of the two following criteria (33)T≈ f=[I≈+S≈Esh:C-1≈m:(C≈ f-C≈ m)]-1 where τn→(1,i)±θ,γn→(1,i)±θ are the normal shear stress and shear strain on a crack in the (1,i) plane making an angle of ±θ with respect to the direction 1 and (τt→(1,i)±θ,γt→(1,i)±θ) are the tangential shear stress and shear strain on a crack in the (1, i) plane making an angle of ±θ with respect to the direction 1. (en→ 1-,gn→ 1-,gt→ 1-) are material parameters (see for instance Ref. [5] for the definition of τt→ (1,i)±θ,γt→ (1,i)±θ). Y~1- is the effective threshold of the fibre compression criterion. This value is a function of an initial value (Y1- 0 which represents the strength without any defect) and of the microdamages (through the parameter h1-). This criterion is activated only if the normal energy in the fibre (which initiates this mode of failure) is sufficient (in a practical manner it means that σ1ɛ1>gn→ 1-/4.

Rupture in transverse (in-plane or through-the-thickness) compressive loadings leads to a crack in the (2,3) plane which makes an angle of ±α with respect to the direction axis 3 (for the in-plane transverse compressive loadings) or to the direction 2 (for the through-thickness transverse compressive loadings). The compressive transverse in-plane (f2 -) and through-thickness (f3 -) criteria are given by (34)T≈ f=[I≈+S≈Esh:C-1≈m:(C≈ f-C≈ m)]-1 where (τn→ (i,j)±α,γn→ (i,j)±α) are the normal shear stress and shear strain on a crack in the (i, j) plane making an angle of ±α with respect to the direction i and (τn→ (i,j)±α,γn→ (i,j)±α) are the tangential shear stress and shear strain on a crack in the (i,j) plane making an angle of ±α with respect to the direction i. (en→ i-,gn→ i-,gt→ i-) are material parameters (see Figure 2). Y~i- is the threshold of the transverse (in-plane i = 2 or through-thickness i = 3) compression criterion. This value is a function of an initial value (Y1- 0 which represents the strength without any defect) and of the microdamages (balanced with the parameter hi-). For the sake of simplicity, it has been supposed that α = θ = 45°. The development of the angle θ has been extensively studied by Soutis et al, Refs [21–23] and this is also examined in Refs [16,17]. Figure 4.
Comparison between model and experiment for the non-linear behaviour of the epoxy 2 matrix.

sec.title: MHM model to describe the progressive failure of laminates
sec.p: In this section, we will consider the change of scale from the UD ply to the laminate. Two points are investigated: (1) the effect of a failed ply on the behaviour of the laminate and (2) the non-linear 3D meso to macro change of scale.

The progressive degradation model is based on damage models. When the failure criterion value is higher than one, the ply is broken and its mechanical properties are progressively degraded (due to the load transfer from the other sound plies in the laminate) (35)S~≈=S≈0+∑idiH≈i eff where S≈ ~ and S0 are, respectively, the damaged and the initial compliance tensors. diH≈i eff are tensors that represent the effect of the failure mode on the compliance of the failed ply. For each degradation model, a distinction is made between the kinetics of degradation with the scalar variables di and the effect of failure on the mesoscopic behaviour. In the framework of this exercise, for the sake of simplicity, we have considered that FF (in tension or in compression) and interfibre compression failure are catastrophic for the laminate. Consequently, the degradation model is only applied to the failure criteria f2+ and f3+.
The degradation variables d2 and d3 associated to the failure criteria f2+ and f3+ are given by (36)di=αiáYi eqYi 0-1ñ+ and d·i≥0for>i=(2,3)

The kinetic parameters αi are material parameters that must be identified. The evolution of the degradation variable is positive in order to ensure the Clausius-Duhem inequality24 (this model is thermodynamically consistent). This condition permits also to describe a realistic behaviour even under complex loading/unloading paths. Figure 5.
Comparison between model and experimental results12,13 when uniaxial tensile failure is due to crazing, and when the triaxial tensile strength is known. Figure 6.
Comparison between model and experimental results12,13 when uniaxial tensile failure is due to yielding, and when the triaxial tensile strength is known. Figure 7.
Comparison between model and experiment for the non-linear behaviour in compression for all the UD considered in the exercise.

The effect tensors are different if the ply is under tensile Hi + or compressive loadings Hi +, the cracks being opened or closed (see Appendix 1). (37)H≈i eff=ηiH≈i ++(1-ηi)H≈i -for>i=(2,3) Hi + and Hi - are determined through a micromechanical approach25 (based on failure mechanics26), which only necessitates the knowledge of the elastic properties of the UD ply. Consequently, no additional test is necessary for the identification of these effect tensors. The FFs (tension and compression) and transverse compression failures (inducing an explosive wedge effect27) are considered as ultimate failures for laminates. The ηi activation index allows to distinguish the opened cracks (ηi = 1 if σi≥0) from the closed ones (ηi = 0 σi<0), which is essential in order to predict failure, not only for non-proportional tests but also for some proportional tests subjected to multiaxial loadings (see Appendix 1). Figure 8.
Comparison between model and experiment for the non-linear behaviour in shear loading for all the UD considered in the exercise.

In the present paper, because of the limitation of the classical laminate theory to in-plane loadings, the 3D meso/macro change of scale is achieved using the transformation field analysis (TFA). We recall here the main lines of the TFA method. The reader can find more information in Refs [28,29]. Basically, the TFA method is based on an RVE (in the present case the laminate) which is divided into a number of sub-volumes (i.e. the UD plies constituting the laminate) inside which the mechanical fields is assumed uniform. The local stress and strain fields are connected to the macroscopic ones by relations using localization (A≈r and B≈r where r denotes the sub-volume r) and influence tensors (F≈rs and D≈rs where the subscript rs denotes the influence of sub-volume s on sub-volume r). These fourth order tensors are functions of the elastic behaviour of each sub-volume and of the shape of the RVE. In case of varying local elastic behaviour (induced by damage for instance) these tensors must be recalculated at each increment of the problem. Chaboche et al.30 have modified the TFA model to overcome this limitation. The Generalized TFA is thus written as follows (38)σ~r=B≈r:Σ~-∑sF≈rs:L≈s:ɛ~s g (39)T≈ f=[I≈+S≈Esh:C-1≈m:(C≈ f-C≈ m)]-1 where ɛ~s g is a generalized eigenstrain (which can be a function of the stress) taking into account all the non-linearities. This eigenstrain is written as (40)ɛ~s g=(I≈-C≈s 0:C≈ ~s -1):(ɛ~s-ɛ~s ve-ɛ~s th) where ɛ~s ve and ɛ~s th are, respectively, the viscoelastic and the thermal strain of the sub-volume s. C≈ ~s -1 and C≈s 0 are, respectively, the damaged and initial stiffness tensors of the sub-volume s.
Finally, the quantities at the macroscopic scale are given by (41)Σ~=áσ~(x)ñV=∑rvrσ~r (42)E~=áɛ~(x)ñV=∑rvrɛ~r where vr is the volume fraction of sub-volume r.

The main difficulty of this method is the calculation of the localization and influence tensors. They could be determined once for all using an analytical method for which one sub-volume is considered for each ply. In each sub-volume, the stresses and the strains are constant. It is supposed that the in-plane strains are equal in all the plies (same hypothesis than the classical laminate theory for in-plane loadings and symmetric laminate composites). At each interface, the transverse components of the stress should be continuous, which yields to equal out-of-plane stresses in all the plies. The determination of the localization and influence tensors are given in Appendix 2.

sec.title: Procedure to identify the model
sec.p:
The aim of this section is to present an identification procedure for the matrix failure criterion, for the matrix behaviour and for the MHM behaviour and the MHM failure criterion. Figure 9.
Determination of the f2 + and f2 - micromechanical-based hybrid mesoscopic (MHM) criteria form the knowledge of the in-plane ply strengths and the in-plane mesoscopic criterion. The continuous line is the MHM criterion and the dotted line the mesoscopic criterion. Part A-B is used to calculate Yt 0 and h2t. Part B-C is used to determine S12 0 and h12t. Part C-D is used to calculate gn→ 2-,gt→ 2- and h2-.

The matrix behaviour necessitates identifying the parameters given in Table 1. The present model allows describing complex behaviours (for instance effect of loading rate, creep tests…), its complete identification necessitates using a tensile creep test. In the framework of this exercise, tensile and compressive tests on the different matrices have been used. Consequently, the identification necessitates to make some choices (based on our knowledge of classical polymer matrices, see Table 1). Table 1.
Parameters for the non-linear behaviour of the matrix. The role of each parameter and the associated equations are given in column “Role”. The procedure to identify each parameter is given in the column “Comments”
Role Comments Value

Emr, νmr Viscoelastic properties, equation (8) Obtained from the initial part of the measured stress/strain compressive curve of the matrices See Figure 4
p, σ0 Definition of the non-linear function g, equation (10) Obtained from the last part of the measured stress/strain compressive curve of the matrices See Figure 4
a, b, c Definition of the equivalent stress used in the non-linear function, equations (10) and (11) c is given by the difference of behaviour between traction and compression. a and b are chosen in order to be representative of classical epoxy resin c (see Figure 4) a = 1; b = 0a
n0, nc Spectrum for the relaxation time (τi) and its weight (mi), equation (9) Chosen in order to be representative of classical epoxy resin n0 = 12a nc = 8a
a
For the whole exercise.

The multimechanism failure criterion of the matrix necessitates to identify 4 parameters (σs0 and μ for the yielding criterion; σceq and m for the crazing criterion). The yielding criterion could be identified with the knowledge of the uniaxial compressive strength (YmC) and the shear strength Sm (43)σs 0=Smandμ=12-SmYmC

For the crazing criterion, three cases could be envisaged
Uniaxial tensile failure is due to brittle failure without yielding, and the triaxial tensile strength (noted PT) is known (see Figure 5). In this case,
(44)σc eq=YmTand>m=log(3)log(YmT/PT)
Uniaxial tensile failure is due to yielding and the triaxial tensile strength (noted PT) is known (see Figure 6). In this case, in order to be at least conservative, m is chosen equal to 1 and σc eq=3PT
If the triaxial tensile strength is not known (which is the case in the present exercise), in order to be conservative, σc eq and m are, respectively, chosen equal to YmT and 1.

The MHM mesoscopic behaviour necessitates identifying the parameters given in Table 2. If the non-linear behaviour of the matrix is known, it is possible to deduce the parameters of the ply from those of the matrix (see Table 2). However, due to the lack of confidence in the micro/meso change of scale, updating of some parameters is possible. Similarly, the present model permits to describe a complex behaviour (for instance the effect of loading rate), its complete identification necessitates using two tensile creep tests. In the framework of this exercise, compressive tests on the different UD plies have been used. For this reason, the identification necessitates to make some choices (based on our knowledge of classical UD ply, see Table 2). Table 2.
Parameters for the non-linear behaviour of the UD ply. The role of each parameter and the associated equations are given in column “Role”. The procedure to identify each parameter is given in the column “Comments”

The MHM microdamage model necessitates identifying the parameters given in Table 3. The present model permits to describe complex effects (such as crack closure during non-proportional tests). In the framework of this exercise, in-plane shear tests on the different UD plies have been used. Consequently, the identification necessitates to make some choices (based on our knowledge of classical UD ply, see Table 3). For instance, the parameters of the thermodynamic force have been chosen equal for all the composites. Moreover, the crack closure has been de-activated because there is no test available to identify these parameters. However, a correct identification of these parameters could permit to improve some test cases. Some values of tensor K≈m (K12, K21, K13, K31) (relation (26)) are very low as compared with the other ones. These terms are induced by the tensor B≈m, in which the authors have only a limited confidence, due to the micro-meso consistence problem mentioned previously. The thermodynamic forces could be very sensitive to these terms (especially for loadings in the fibre direction); therefore, we have decided to nullify these terms. However, a correct identification of this parameter could permit to improve some test cases involving fibre compressive failure (especially test cases 6 and 7). In fact, the present model allows taking into account the effect of the microdamages on the compressive failure criterion, but these simplifications (especially on K≈m) lead to no microdamage for axial compressive loadings. Figure 10.
Determination of the f1 + and f1 - micromechanical-based hybrid mesoscopic (MHM) criteria from the knowledge of the in-plane ply strengths and the in-plane mesoscopic criterion. Point B is used to calculate gn→ 1-and h1-. Part C-D is used to determine gt→ 1- and h1-. Table 3.
Parameters for the microdamage model. The role of each parameter and the associated equations are given in column “Role”. The procedure to identify each parameter is given in the column “Comments”
Role Comments Value
H≈i ve Effect of microdamages on the viscoelastic compliance, equation (22) The microdamage has an effect only on the shear behaviour h33 2ve=h22 2ve=0 a h44 2ve=h66 2ve=1a h44 3ve=h66 3ve=1a

For the whole exercise.

The MHM mesoscopic criterion necessitates identifying the parameters given in Table 4. The terms Yi± 0 are fixed to 1. All the parameters of the MHM failure criterion are identified using the strengths provided by the organizers. In fact, the strategy consists in identifying the in-plane strength without damage (strength noted with the upscript 0) and the effect of damage on these strengths in order to obtain results very close to those obtained using the more simple 2D criterion previously proposed by the authors (see Figures 9 and 10). The ply is considered to be transverse isotropic leading to equivalent in-plane and through-thickness values. Due to lack of data on the transverse shear behaviour, the transverse shear strength parameters (effect of damage and “virtual” strength without damage) are identified assuming that the ratio, strength vs “virtual” strength, is the same as the ratio previously determined for the in-plane shear strength. Finally, the kinetics of damage due to the rupture of a ply in tensile IFF mode has to be identified through a laminate. Due to the lack of data and for the sake of simplicity, in the present study, we have used classical values obtained on glass/epoxy (α2=6) or carbon epoxy (α2=4) laminates. Due to lack of data, the through-thickness tensile rupture is considered to be quasi-catastrophic (α3=10).

It has been verified that the MHM model permits to obtain accurate results for in-plane loadings. Figure 11 shows the comparison between model and experimental results from the first WWFE. These results are close to those obtained by the previous criterion proposed by the authors.2,3 Figure 11.
(a) Biaxial failure envelope of the E-glass/MY750 unidirectional ply under combined σ11 and σ22 stresses. (b) Biaxial failure envelope of the E-Glass/MY750 [±55°]s laminate under combined Σxx and Σyy macroscopic stresses (Test data from Ref. [1]).

The following sentences have been added: The results in Figure 11 are for in-plane biaxial loadings, see Ref. [1]. The left hand side graph is for a unidirectional lamina under combined longitudinal and transverse stresses. For the right hand side graph, the laminate analysed was made of ±55° and this was subjected to combined direct stresses. The predicted trend is regarded to be good in relation to the predictions of other 19 models that are benchmarked in Ref. [1].

sec.title: Results on the different test cases
sec.p: We propose a unified definition of the final failure of a laminate. To attain this goal, it is necessary to quantify the effect of the different cracks (due to fibre and IFF) on the macroscopic behaviour. We proposed to use a normalized and directional indicator that permits to quantify by a scalar value the loss of macroscopic rigidity in the loading directions (even for multiaxial tests) defined by (45)Es=tΣ~:S≈0 macro:Σ~tΣ~:S~≈macro:Σ~ where S≈ 0macro and S≈ ~macro are, respectively, the initial compliance of the laminate and the macroscopic degraded compliance due to the ply failures in the laminate and where Σ~ is the macroscopic stress in the loading axis.

If the laminate is undamaged, the indicator remains equal to 1. When some cracks appear in the plies, the macroscopic compliance is progressively increased due to the degraded mechanical properties of the failed plies; the indicator decreases progressively and tends asymptotically to 0. In the following, a laminate, which has lost more than 50% of its macroscopic rigidity, is considered as broken.

It is worth mentioning that, for the sake of simplicity, in the present exercise, it has been supposed that the FFs and interfibre compressive failures are catastrophic. This point will be addressed in the part B of this exercise.

Residual thermal stresses have been taken into account for the modelling of laminates (for a ply, there is of course no mesoscopic thermal residual stress). In the following, because of a lack of information on the manufacturing process of the laminates, the stress free temperature T0 is assumed to be reduced by 50% to take into account the effect of moisture absorption after cooling (due to atmosphere humidity) on the residual thermal stresses.

The implementation of the present approach has been performed using a numerical scheme presented in Ref. [32]. A software based on Matlab© language has been developed to perform the analysis presented in the following paragraphs. This approach has been implemented in an FE code (ZéBuLoN) and its validation is under progress.

sec.title: Test case 1
sec.p:
The first test case concerns the variation of the compressive strength (σ11) of the MY750 resin as a function of the stress component σ22(=σ33). The predicted failure envelope is shown in Figure 12. Two main modes of failure are shown (a) crazing along the AB curve and yielding elsewhere. For the crazing failure, and due to the fact that the organisers of the WWFE have not supplied the authors with the required input, assumptions were made to facilitate the prediction. The values used in the prediction of crazing, using equation (14) are m = 1 and σc eq = YmT (uniaxial tensile strength of the matrix). The use of m = 1 produces a linearised relationship between the three stresses (σ11, σ22, σ33). Figure 12.
(Result for test case 1) Variation of the strength (σ11) of polymeric resin matrix (MY750) with stress σ22 (=σ33).

The other two branches of the envelope extending into the compression–compression domain represent failure by yielding, based on equation (13). The required parameters (σs 0 and μ) are given in equation (43). It should be noted here the envelope is open and the material is not predicted to fail under hydrostatic pressure (i.e. under −σ11 = −σ22 = −σ33). The open envelope has also been predicted by other failure criteria, see Ref. [33].

sec.title: Test cases 2–4
sec.p:
The second test case concerns the variation of the shear strength (τ12) as a function of the stress component σ22(=σ11 = σ33) for the UD T300/PR-319 ply. The results are presented in Figure 13. The increase of the in-plane shear strength is due to the decrease of damage under transverse compressive loading (use of the positive part of the matrix deformation to calculate the damage equation (25)). For high levels of hydrostatic compressive loading, the shear strength tends to the limit value S12 0 (164.2 MPa for the T300/PR-319 material). Figure 13.
(Result for test case 2) Variation of shear strength (τ12) with stress σ22(=σ11 = σ33) for a UD T300/PR-319 ply.

The effect of the hydrostatic pressure on the non-linear shear behaviour of a UD carbon/epoxy is the object of the third and of the fourth test cases. In the present MHM model, the non-linear behaviour is described by a spectral viscoelastic modelling. The effect of the hydrostatic pressure is taken into account with the parameters aUD, bUD and cUD. Moreover, microdamage has also an influence on the viscoelastic behaviour. On one hand, under shear loading, the evolution of the microdamages increases but, on the other hand, superposed hydrostatic pressure decreases the evolution of this microdamage. Figure 14 shows the variation of the failure shear strain (γ12) as a function of the stress component σ22(=σ11 = σ33) for the UD T300/PR319 ply. Figure 15 presents the shear stress/shear strain curve (τ12 versus γ12) for the UD T300/PR319 ply for σ22 = σ11 = σ33 = −600 MPa. The non-linear behaviour is described through the spectral viscoelastic model that takes into account the effects of the hydrostatic pressure and of the microdamages on the viscoelasticity. Figure 14.
(Result for test case 3): Variation of failure shear strain (γ12) with stress σ22(=σ11 = σ33) for a UD T300/PR-319 ply. Figure 15.
(Result for test case 4) Shear stress / shear strain curve (τ12 versus γ12) for a UD T300/PR-319 ply for σ11 = σ22 = σ33 = −600 MPa.

sec.title: Test case 5
sec.p:
The test case 5 concerns the variation of the transverse compressive strength σ22 as a function of the stress component σ33 (where σ11 = σ33) for the UD E-Glass/MY-750 ply. The results are reported in Figure 16. Concerning the failure mode, in part A-B, failure occurs by through-thickness tensile rupture. In part B-C, failure is due to transverse tensile rupture. In the other parts of the curve (beyond points C and A), rupture occurs by transverse compressive failure. Concerning the shape of the curve, it is worth mentioning that the slope of the curve evolves as a function of the involved micromechanisms. For instance, in part A-D, by Poisson’s effect, microdamages are created (μ3). As the σ11 and σ33 loads increase, this microdamage decreases leading to an increase in the strength. From point D, microdamage is no more created. Figure 16.
(Result for test case 5) Variation of transverse strength σ22 with σ33 (where σ11 = σ33) for a UD E-Glass/MY-750 ply.

As for test case 1, the hydrostatic pressure leads to an infinite strength. It is well known that for polymer matrix composites, the hydrostatic pressure has a strong influence on the strength. In fact, in a real test, failure could be initiated by a local defect (too close fibres, local porosity). In the present exercise, there is not any experimental evidence of such a phenomenon. As a function of the results provided in the part B of this exercise, this point will be addressed later.

sec.title: Test cases 6 and 7
sec.p:
Test cases 6 and 7 concern the evolution of the longitudinal strength σ11 with through-thickness stress (σ33 = σ22) for the UD S2-glass/epoxy2 (case 6) and the UD A-S carbon/epoxy (case 7) plies. The results are given in Figures 17 and 18, respectively. In part A-B, the rupture occurs by tensile FF. In part B-C, rupture is due to transverse (in-plane or through-the-thickness) tensile failure. For compressive/compressive loadings, rupture occurs by compressive FF. Rupture by fibre compressive failure is due to the creation of a shear band. In our point of view, this shear band is very sensitive to local defects and could be initiated from microdamages. However, due to the lack of confidence in the local properties, the effect of longitudinal loading on the microdamage has been de-activated, leading to a weak confidence in the results obtained for this mode of failure. Moreover, the compressive/compressive part of the curve is very sensitive to the value of the Poisson’s ratio ν23, a point which is arguable. These points will be addressed in the part B of the exercise. Figure 17.
(Result for test case 6) Variation of the longitudinal strength σ11 with through-thickness stress (σ33 = σ22) for a UD S2-glass/epoxy 2 ply. Figure 18.
(Result for test case 7) Variation of the longitudinal strength σ11 with through-thickness stress (σ33 = σ22) for a UD A-S carbon/epoxy 1 ply.

sec.title: Test cases 8,9
sec.p:
Test case 8 concerns the variation of the axial compressive strength σy as a function of the through-thickness stress component Σzz (=Σxx) for the [+35°/−35°]s E-glass/MY-750 laminate. The results are shown in Figure 19. In part A-B, rupture occurs by tensile interfibre rupture. It is important to note that delamination could occur in this part. Compressive rupture occurs in part B-C (interfibre mode) and in part A-D (fibre mode). The failure predictions in compressive FF, for part A-D, have to be considered cautiously (same explanations as for test cases 6-7). It is worth mentioning that even for quasi hydrostatic loadings, failure is predicted by the present model, but the predicted macroscopic strengths are too large. Figure 19.
(Result for test case 8) Variation of the axial strength Σyy with through-thickness stress Σzz (where Σzz = Σxx) for [+35°/−35°]s E-glass/MY-750 laminate.

Test case 9 is concerned with the axial compressive stress/strain curves for the [+35°/-35°]s E-Glass/MY-750 laminate under (Σzz = Σxx = −100 MPa) loadings (see Figure 20). The MHM model shows that the behaviour is non-linear (due to viscoelasticity) and the final rupture is due to fibre compressive failure. Figure 20.
(Result for test case 9) Axial compressive stress/strain curves for [+35°/−35°]s E-glass/MY-750 laminate under Σzz = Σxx = −100 MPa.
The effect of thermal residual stresses is not significant for these test cases.

sec.title: Test cases 10–12
sec.p:
Test cases 10 and 11 concern the variation of the through-thickness shear stress (Σzx) versus through-thickness normal stress (Σzz) for the [+45°/−45°/90°/0°]s and the [0/90°]s IM7/8551-7 laminates. The results are presented in Figures 21 and 22. Figure 21.
(Result for test case 10) Variation of the through-thickness shear strength (Σyz) versus through-thickness stress (Σzz) for [+45°/−45°/90°/0°]s IM7/8551-7 laminate. Figure 22.
(Result for test case 11) Variation of the through-thickness shear strength (Σyz) versus through-thickness stress (Σzz) for [0°/90°]s IM7/8551-7 laminate.

Concerning the first ply failure, in part A-B, rupture occurs by through-thickness tensile failure of the 0° plies. Due to lack of data, the kinetics of degradation associated to this mode is quasi-catastrophic, which could lead to conservative results. It is important to note that delamination could occur in this part. In parts B-C and C-D, failure occurs by transverse failure of the 0° plies. Finally, in part D-E, failure occurs by through-thickness compressive failure of the 0° plies. As explained previously, due to lack of data, this mode has been considered as catastrophic, which could lead to too conservative results. This point will be addressed in the part B of this exercise, Ref. [16].

Concerning the last ply failure, in part A-B, the final failure is due to a loss of rigidity (equation (45)); all the plies have failed in the through-thickness tensile mode. In part B-C, all the plies (except the 90° ply) are broken in the through-thickness tensile mode and the final failure is due to a loss of rigidity. In part C-D, the final failure occurs by through-thickness compressive failure of the 0° plies. Finally, in part D-E, the first ply failure leads to the final failure.

Finally, the last test case concerns the compressive through-thickness stress/strain curves for the [0°/90°]s IM7/8551-7 laminate. Results are shown in Figure 23. The predicted behaviour is highly non-linear due to the effect of microdamage on the viscoelastic MHM model and the final failure is due to interfibre compressive failure of all the plies. Figure 23.
(Result for test case 12) Compressive through-thickness stress/strain curves for a [0°/90°]s IM7/8551-7 laminate.

For these test cases, the thermal residual stresses have an influence especially on the prediction of the final rupture when interfibre compressive failure is involved (as reported in Figures 24–26). As will be shown in Ref. [33], the effects of the thermal stresses predicted by other models, including those based on micromechanics, depend upon the type of analysis performed (linear versus non-linear) and on the types of failure criteria used. Figure 24.
Influence of the thermal residual stresses on the variation of the through-thickness shear strength (Σyz) versus through-thickness stress (Σzz) for [+45°/−45°/90°/0°]s IM7/8551-7 laminate. Figure 25.
Influence of the thermal residual stresses on the variation of the through-thickness shear strength (Σyz) versus through-thickness stress (Σzz) for [0°/90°]s IM7/8551-7 laminate. Figure 26.
Influence of the thermal residual stresses on the compressive through-thickness stress/strain curves for [0°/90°]s IM7/8551-7 laminate.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In order to predict the ply failure sequence in a laminate until the final failure, a multiscale MHM 3D progressive failure approach was developed. The principle of this hybrid model is to introduce micromechanical aspects (such as the effect of the local debonding on the non-linear behaviour or on the failure) at the mesoscopic scale.

The evolution of the microdamages (fibre/matrix debonding, microcracks into the matrix) was described by a damage model. The evolution of this microdamage is correlated to the elastic strain into the matrix. This strain is calculated using a simple localization rule. However, due to the lack of confidence in the local (fibre and matrix) properties, some terms involved in this local deformation seems arguable (see equation (26)). This point could have a great influence on different aspects (for instance the effect of debondings on the strength in fibre compression) and will be addressed in the Part B of this exercise, Ref. [16]. It is worth mentioning here that the effect of defects at the fibre/matrix interface on the stability of the axial fibres when the composite laminate is loaded in axial or biaxial compression has also been examined in Refs [34,35].

It has been evidenced that it is essential to describe accurately the mesoscopic behaviour in order to predict ply failures especially under hydrostatic pressure. To address this point, the non-linear behaviour is described by a viscoelastic spectral model which takes into account the effect of the hydrostatic pressure on the non-linear behaviour. Moreover, an improvement of the MHM model concerns the description of the effect of the microdamages on this viscosity.

The ply criterion proposed in this study introduces a distinction between the FF and the IFFs. Moreover, a distinction is made between compressive and tensile ruptures. Introducing the effects of microdamages in the FF and IFF criteria is the main improvement proposed in the present model. It leads to a better description of the strength of the UD ply under shear and transverse loadings. Nevertheless, in the present failure approach, the FF under compressive loadings is not totally satisfactory. In our opinion, the proposed scenario based on the initiation by microdamages of a shear band described by an energy criterion is realistic. But, as explained previously, some simplifications in the identification process have been made, due to the lack of confidence in the fibre and matrix properties. This point will be addressed in the part B of this exercise.

The degradation due to ply failure is described by a damage model. This model decreases progressively the effective stiffness of the failed ply in the laminate. Degradation due to FF and degradation due to IFF are characterised separately. For each degradation model, a distinction is made between the kinetics of degradation (i.e. evolution of the crack density) and the effect of failure (different for closed and opened cracks) on the mesoscopic behaviour. For the sake of simplicity, and due to lack of data, compressive rupture has been supposed to be catastrophic. This assumption seems to be correct for in-plane loadings. However, for interfibre compressive failure, it is possible that combined in-plane and through-thickness loadings delayed the effect of this damage. This point will be addressed in the Part B of this exercise, Ref. [16].

It is worth pointing out here that size effects and environmental effects (temperature, moisture content) do affect the damage initiation/propagation. Some of these are addressed in Refs [36–38] and in the third WWFE, where the authors have made a contribution, Ref. [17].

Computation of the localization and influence tensors for the meso/macro change of scale31

In the following, the components of tensors are noted according to the Voigt convention i.e. the in-plane quantities (L) refer to 1,2 and 6 subscripts and the out-of-plane quantities (T) refer to 3, 4 and 5 subscripts.

For the sake of simplicity, the splitting into transversal (T) and longitudinal (L) parts of the fourth-order tensors are used. For instance, the tensors X≈ become 3 × 3 matrices (X¯¯ refers to a 3 × 3 matrix): (51)LLX¯¯=(X11X12X16X21X22X26X61X62X66) LTX¯¯=(X13X15X14X23X25X24X63X65X64)TLX¯¯=(X31X32X36X51X52X56X41X462X46) TTX¯¯i=(X33X35X34X53X55X54X43X46X44)
We also use some abbreviations (52)γ¯¯i=(TTC¯¯i)-1:TLC¯¯i η¯¯i=(TTC¯¯i)-1

and their averages (53)γ¯¯=∑i=1 Nviγ¯¯i η¯¯=∑i=1 Nviη¯¯i where the subscript i refers to the layer i. C≈i is the elastic stiffness tensor of ply i written in the loading coordinates system and vi is the volume fraction of ply i.

The split strain and influence tensors are given by (54)T≈ f=[I≈+S≈Esh:C-1≈m:(C≈ f-C≈ m)]-1 and (55)LLD¯¯ij=0¯¯ LTD¯¯ij=0¯¯TLD¯¯i=δijγ¯¯i-vjη¯¯i:η-1:γ¯¯j TTD¯¯ij=δijI¯¯-vjη¯¯i:η¯¯-1 where δij is Kronecker symbol (1 if i = j, 0 in the other cases).
Finally, the strain localization tensors and influence tensors are obtained from equations (54) and (55), using the definition given in equation (51).
